text:
welcome to how to cook that I'm Ann
Reardon and it's that time of year again

when it's getting close to Christmas
this year I decided to make a

gravity-defying gingerbread house
inspired by the UP movie house

I made a simpler version of this many
years ago and I didn't film how to make

it I just made it and took a few photos
so this time I'm going to try and make

it even better the first thing you'll
need to do is print out the template

that I made all those years ago now if
any gingerbread house has this many

pieces you should know that it's a
complicated one and probably not for

beginners I have this gingerbread house
template and several other easier ones

on the howtocookthat.net website for you
and all the recipe quantities and

details that I've used in this house are
there too I am going to make a couple of

adjustments last time I made all the
balcony rails out of gingerbread and

this time I'm going to do them out of
fondant so they can be a bit finer and a

bit more detailed so I'm just going to
get rid of those bits from the template

now to make the gingerbread dough we are
going to need three batches of this for

each batch we have flour sugar and then
for our syrups we have molasses and

glucose syrup you can swap this for corn
syrup and you can swap this for golden

syrup or honey but it will affect the
flavor the color and the texture of your

dough we have milk butter and then we
have our spices and baking powder with

the spices I've got cloves cinnamon and
ginger you can vary the amounts of these

completely or leave them out whatever
flavor you want muck around with the

spices all you like first thing we need
to do is melt our butter and you can do

that in the microwave or on the stove
top and then add in the sugar and the

glucose syrup and the molasses and give
that a stir then you can add in your

milk and again give it a stir around and
then it's time to add the flour and all

your spices whatever you've chosen to
put in there and the baking powder and

stir that all together
until you have a thick soft dough tip

that gingerbread dough
some plastic wrap and wrap it up firmly

and you want to place that in the fridge
and as the butter cools down your dough

is going to get thicker and we need to
make of course the two more batches of

this you couldn't make it all at once
unless you have a ginormous mixing bowl

next I want you to lay out all your
template pieces onto pieces of baking

paper so you know which pieces will fit
on which trays and how many trays you're

going to need so you know how much you
need to split your dough up between the

trays put the dough onto some baking
paper sprinkle it with some flour on top

so the rolling pin doesn't stick and
roll it out to the size of your tray

place your pieces on top and cut around
the template now you can see here I've

cut around the template but then I've
also left a gap or a border of dough and

the reason I've done that is to fold the
one because it helps stop it spreading

out and true it stops the corners from
burning in the oven now the other

important thing is to make sure you take
the template off before you bake it I've

forgotten to do that before and then the
template sticks and also halfway through

baking pull it out and redo these cuts
just to make sure that they stay all the

way through rather than fusing together
so slide that onto a baking tray and

bake it in the oven once it is baked and
cooled check your pieces of firm enough

I've got some of the scraps here to show
you this one is really soft and this one

is really hard and it's the exact same
dough the only difference is how long it

was baked for so if it's soft after its
cooled just chuck it back in the oven

for a little bit longer just to dry it
out give it an extra five or ten minutes

and then cool it again and you should be
good to go once all the pieces are baked

and cooled lay out the backside and
front walls and I always used to use

royal icing for putting gingerbread
houses together but now I quite like

using compound chocolate because it sets
firm faster you'll notice here that I

have the back wall on the inside and the
side walls on the outside that makes a

difference as to how everything fits
together and I've cut myself a baseboard

in the shape of the house and put a hole
in it you'll need to do that too if

you're wanting it to float if you don't
want it to float you can just you

is a blank board in a normal shape
rectangle board to put your house on at

the front wall and then the three bits
of the bay window now before you add

chocolate to these check that they all
sit neatly together because the

gingerbread can spread out a bit and
it's quite thick you may need to just

sort of adjust them slightly the best
way to do that is using a fine grater

and just grate some of the ginger bread
off so that they fit together on that

angle there then add that little bit
just next to the front door now this

area here is raised for the front porch
so add that rectangle into place there

and then the front piece across at the
bottom and then also at the top of the

porch there's another piece that goes
across there now before we put the roof

on you need to decide what you want to
do with your windows do you want to

leave them plain or do you want to put
some gelatin sheets on the inside so

that you can't just see straight in so
that it gives that sort of window a look

I'm gonna go with the gelatin sheets and
I'm just attaching them with white

chocolate add the ledge to the top of
the bay window and over the porch as

well and then put the section above the
bay window into place then add the

sticky out bits on the side section of
the house and then you can start adding

all your roof pieces now you can see why
this template had so many parts it's

quite a complicated house design because
when they were designing it for the

movie they weren't thinking about people
making it as a gingerbread house clearly

before you put this last bit of roof on
you will need to make two decisions one

do you want lollies or lights inside
your house and two do you want the

balloon coming out of the chimney
because if you do you need to put the

support rod into place now otherwise
you're not going to be able to secure it

in there first things first if you want
it to float you're going to need a big

solid
MDF board with a nut underneath holding

the rod in and a washer and a nut on top
and make sure you've tightened that

really well decide what height you want
it has to be floating add another nut

there and then
had a washer and then add the house down

over the top and support that with your
hand while you try and screw another nut

all the way down and support rod down to
the top of the board inside the house

and then tighten that up from the
underneath again this needs to be really

tight to hold it in place you probably
should use a wooden board for under the

house rather than cardboard but I didn't
because I didn't want to saw the wooden

board hopefully it is strong enough to
hold and then you can add the last two

big pieces of roof into place and I've
just cut an extra piece out on this so

that it will fit around the rod there at
the little extra window and the two

little roof pieces on that side there on
the front and now for the balloon I have

another piece of rod and a coupler so
that I can join it to the rod coming out

of the house for the balloon put some
marshmallows into a bowl and microwave

them until they are melted look at that
gooey melted marshmallows then add in

rice bubbles and stir them together and
yes they are called rust bubbles here in

Australia that's what it says on the
packet and that's what we call them I

like to use cheaper chuyia marshmallows
for this because they set a bit firmer

than the soft ones line a bowl with
baking paper and scoop in the

marshmallow rust bubble mixture and push
it down firmly if it's sticking to your

hands just dampen your hands slightly
add the central support rod and to give

that a bit more support and pouring in
some melted compound white chocolate

that's just going to grip onto the metal
rod and also spread out of it it stays

firm and together I'm using some sticky
tape just to support that rod while I

add more of the marshmallow mixture if
you've got someone who can just hold it

for you that will do to make another
batch and build it up on top of the bowl

until you get a nice balloon shape once
you're happy with the shape you can

cover the whole thing in deep blue
fondant then using a little bit of water

add a sugared almond or whatever candy
you think looks like individual balloons

onto your big balloon
using just water worked fine to attach

them when the balloon was sloping but
when it got too vertical there started

sliding off so I'm going to have to let
that side dry before turning it over and

doing the other side it's now 3 a.m. in
the morning so I'm going to hit the bed

and continue this tomorrow
moving on to making the decorations for

the colored cladding I'm just cutting
strips of fondant and I'm going to leave

them to dry out so they're easy to get
onto the house looking perfectly

straight which is quite hard to do with
strips of soft fondant I'm making them a

bit longer than I think they need to be
so that I can just cut them to shape as

we decorate the house this is easy but
it's actually quite repetitive because

all the sides have different coloured
cladding so you need to make lots and

lots and lots of strips of fondant for
the windows lay out thin strips yes more

strips of fondant followed by some more
strips going across

now I've just measured the windows using
a ruler on the house to see how big they

actually are now that it's baked
everything can spread and move a little

bit in gingerbread that's why I'm
measuring it off the baked house and not

off the template leave them to dry out a
bit and then trim off the excess bits

around the edges and then add a border
of light wood color over the top of each

window now around the base of the house
all the way around there's a rectangle

panels of wood with a border of a
different coloured wood over the top now

I've just used my knife to make indents
in the rectangle part so it looks like

it's got diagonal planks but it's just
actually one piece of fondant and then

I'm adding those extra strips around the
edge for the columns on the front of the

house I'm making them out of fondant
rolled quite thickly and then I'm just

cutting a slice to make a square column
once you have three of those cut line

them up together and then just use a
ruler or the back of a knife to indent

them all at the same level then add the
handrail and the spindles and to join

this together just use a little bit of
water and it will join the fondant to

itself the hose reel is of
course an important part of this

gingerbread house because it's used to
pull the house along in the movie so

make a circle of black and then put a
dot of black in the middle and overlay

that with two strips of black and then
trim them to size and leave them to dry

out while you've got your black fondant
out roll out a tiny tiny thin snake of

black and make it into a number one and
a number eight to go on the front pillar

it's tiny details like this which make
the house look really good can you guess

what this next detail is that I'm making
it's certainly not perfect but it's

going to have to do for the weathervane
it's supposed to be a weird-looking

rooster thing that they have poked some
spaghetti into it for the support and

will be able to poke that into the top
of the house now for the strings to hold

the balloons if you want to you can roll
these by hand have fun doing it if not

get a cheap fondant extruder and make
lots of them at once and then straighten

them out and leave them to dry also use
the extruder to make a hose and wrap

that around the reel until you're happy
that you've got enough of the hose on

there make a rectangle out of fondant
and add that into place around the

support rod for your chimney once it is
in the right spot then you can just

shape that and make sure it's square
then add a strip around the top to make

it look a bit more chimney like add some
wood coloured fondant onto the front

porch trim it to shape and then use a
ruler or the back of a knife to just

indent planks where wooden planks would
be moving on to the roof add a strip of

fondant along the bottom of your roof
and indented at various intervals there

and then continue to add more layers up
the roof in slightly different colored

neutral shades of fondant all the way up
to the top add a piece along the bottom

and again I'm using compound chocolate
for this because it sets faster and

holds it really firm you could use royal
icing here if you wanted to though then

add the cladding into place trimming
each one as you go to exactly the right

length and slightly overlapping why
over the top of the next one now I'm

doing the back of the house first so I
can iron out any problems and figure out

anything I'm not happy with before I get
to the front they look pretty good but

if you look at the side here there's a
gap at the corners where they join so on

the front I'm going to need to cut the
side bits on an angle so that it meets

which is going to take a little bit
longer but it'll make it look really

good adding all this cladding took so
long to do over the whole house it does

look good but be warned if you want to
do it it takes a long time add the door

into place and then put a strip of blue
along the roof edges there and add all

the windows into place the underneath of
the roof also needs to be blue so just

use your leftover strips of blue to do
under there

the front of the house has some
fish-scale cladding and I'm doing this

with soft freshly rolled fondant because
it needs to be curved I don't really

have a cutter small enough so I'm just
using bigger fish scale sizing using the

Rose cutter that I had and then adding
that across and I used chocolate

underneath it to make it curved like it
is on the up house then add that window

into place there and onto the bit that
I've been avoiding because it's a fiddly

bit all the front details now to the
left hand side of the house

add in some electrical boxes and some
cords they all flash and make noises

when the house first takes off add a
fuse box to the back of the house and

then get some more sleep
because that's been a really fun day the

next day get someone strong and handsome
to help you lift up the balloon so you

can attach it using the coupler thanks
Dave ... and then you can add the rest of

the sugared almonds now I'm using blue
royal icing now instead of just using

water so that they'll stay on when it's
on the upright slope and that seems to

be much easier then cover the rest of
the balloon with the sugar almonds using

any smaller ones at the top so it looks
like the tops of balloons to cover the

support rod you need to make more
of whites using the fondant extruder and

add them on over the rod just trimming
them off at the bottom once you have

lots of them there I had some of the dry
ones that you made earlier just poking

them into the fondant at the bottom and
using a little bit of royal icing at the

top to hold it onto the balloon now
these are really fragile so if you

intend on moving your gingerbread house
to another person's house to eat it I do

all of these strings once you get there
that way you can transport it with the

balloon off - which would be a bit
easier add in the weathervane that looks

ok now it's on the top of the house and
then to cover the board chop some Oreos

in a food processor or if you don't have
a food processor just put them in a bag

and bash them with a rolling pin that
works just as well cover the foil on the

board with melted chocolate and then
sprinkle under the house where it's just

lifted off with Oreo dirt all the way
under there then cover the rest of the

board with coconut that's been colored
with some green food coloring you just

put it in a bowl add some green food
coloring and mix it through if you're

using gel color you will need to water
it down before you add it in put the

hose reel into place it's not quite
sitting on there because the cladding is

sitting out a bit so I'm just going to
build it up with a couple more bits of

cladding so that it's at the same level
and then add that back on the front

there and at long last after days of
working on it the gingerbread house is

finally finished wow that was a huge
effort I think that it looks pretty cool

though in the end I'd rather it was
floating a little bit higher but there's

no way I'm gonna risk trying to undo
that and move it up I don't even think

that would be possible at this stage but
if you're making it you can do it if you

make this make sure you take a photo of
it and upload it in the comment section

on the website so the rest of the world
can see it - with thanks to my patrons

for supporting this channel you guys are
amazing I wouldn't be able to spend time

doing this sort of thing for you without
your support. Merry Christmas to all of

you! subscribe to how to cook that for
more cool

stuff and watch more of my videos to
help me out make it a great week and
I'll see you on Friday
